*Southshore Marinas - It has been esti-

mated that the Middle Branch could
support over 1,200 boat slips by the
1990s. This will be a dramatic increase
from the approximately 350 slips now
available. As the demand for boat
docking space in the harbor grows
beyond the capacity of existing mari-
nas, a portion of the open space along
the Waterview Avenue shoreline will
become a prime location for marinas,

related commercial development, park-

ing and other water-oriented facilities.
It is also expected that existing private
marinas will expand their service and
number of slips as the future demand
grows.

*Waterview Industrial Center - As indi-

cated above, the Waterview Industrial
Center is a major industrial develop-
ment and redevelopment project
which encompasses 22 existing busi-
nesses and 40 acres of vacant land. The
long-range development plan includes
several public improvements and an
expanded urban renewal ordinance to
promote business expansiors and new
industrial development on the area’s
vacant land. It is expected that over $8
million of private investment and 600
new jobs will be generated by develop-
ment activity in the center at the com-
pletion of the project.

*Carr Lowery - There will be an oppor-

tunity for the Carr Lowery glass manu-
facturing plant to build an additional
furnance adjacent to its current site.

*Water Resources Environmental Center

- As part of the Chesapeake Bay Initia-
tives the State’s Department of Natural
Resources has agreed to fund an
environmental center. The center will
be built on the second level of the
new Baltimore Rowing Club facility
and share meeting space. The center
will provide labs and meeting rooms
for area conservation groups;and spe-
cial educational programs.

*Baltimore Rowing Club - The Balti-

more Rowing Club, with support of
the City will develop a club house and
storage facility. With this quality facility
available the rowing club expects to
generate interest in rowing with
colleges, city schools and expand its
membership.

*Trail System - The Middle Branch Park

Plan called for the creation of a con-

tinuous pedestrian/bike trail that
would link the various segments of the

park together and connect the park
itself to the Inner Harbor, Gwynn Falls
Park, and the 9,000-acre Patapsco State
Park.

Rowing returns to the Middle Branch

*Wetland and Wildlife Habitat Devel-

opment and Interpretation - To com-
pensate for the 136 acres of water
habitat taken by the Canton/Seagirt
dredge spoil disposal site for the 1-95
Fort McHenry Tunnel, the Interstate
Division of Baltimore City is exploring
the feasibility of developing wetlands
in the northern Middle Branch. There
are already signs that this area of
degraded water quality is improving.
Wetland vegetation has reestablished
on several small islands and waterfowl
use the areas. If feasible, an expanded
wetland area could itself help improve
water quality by filtering out some pol-
lutants and providing additional wild-
life habitat.

On the east side of the Reedbird Park,
north and south of the Hanover/Potee
Street bridges, existing wetlands will be
improved and expanded. A program of
wetland and water-life interpretation is
envisioned for the area to instruct park
visitors of the importance of a healthly
environment and improving the har-
bor’s water quality. With the improved
habitat and the connections into the
state park system the Middle Branch
Park will offer a unique opportunity
for environmental groups and the
general public to witness the functions
of the complex ecology of this area.



The Department of Planning is explor-
ing additional wildlife related uses for the
park including fish and wild fowl hatcher-
ies. These would provide a much needed
natural resource and a unique educational
opportunity for City residents.

When completed the Middle Branch
Park will be the largest shorefront park in
the entire harbor. The completed park
system, consisting of the Gwynns Falls,
Middle Branch, Southwest and Patapsco
Valley Parks, will offer over 10,000 acres of
recreational facilities, in one of the most
extensive and varied parks in the country,
to this region’s residents.
